concept.title: Rule 7
concept.shortdesc: A participial phrase at the beginning of a sentence must refer to the grammatical subject.

conbody.lq: Walking slowly down the road, he saw a woman accompanied by two children.
conbody.p: The word walking refers to the subject of the sentence, not to the woman. If the writer wishes to make it refer to the woman, he must recast the sentence:
conbody.lq: He saw a woman accompanied by two children, walking slowly down the road.
conbody.p: Participial phrases preceded by a conjunction or by a preposition, nouns in apposition, adjectives, and adjective phrases come under the same rule if they begin the sentence.

row.entry: On arriving in Chicago, his friends met him at the station.
When he arrived (or, On his arrival) in Chicago, his friends met him at the station.
A soldier of proved valor, they entrusted him with the defence of the city.
A soldier of proved valor, he was entrusted with the defence of the city.
Young and inexperienced, the task seemed easy to me.
Young and inexperienced, I thought the task easy.
Without a friend to counsel him, the temptation proved irresistible.
Without a friend to counsel him, he found the temptation irresistible.

conbody.p: Sentences violating this rule are often ludicrous.
conbody.lq: Being in a dilapidated condition, I was able to buy the house very cheap.
Wondering irresolutely what to do next, the clock struck twelve.
